cleaned_text: Neck](//science.slashdot.org/story/15/05/29/2028238/hacking-your-body-through-a-nerve-in-your-neck) [82](//science.slashdot.org/story/15/05/29/2028238/hacking-your-body-through-a-nerve-in-your-neck#comments) [agent elevator](/~agent+elevator)writes: IEEE Spectrum has a feature (part of its Hacking the Human OS issue) on [the future of vagus nerve stimulation](http://spectrum.ieee.org/biomedical/devices/the-vagus-nerve-a-back-door-for-brain-hacking), a device-based therapy with the potential to treat a ridiculously wide variety of ailments: epilepsy, depression, stroke, tinnitus, heart failure, migraines, asthma, [the list goes on](http://tech.slashdot.org/story/15/01/19/0412237/fda-approves-implantable-vagus-nerve-disruptor-for-weight-loss). One problem is that, because it required an implant (a bit like a pacemaker), it was never anybody's first-choice therapy. But now there's a non-invasive version, a device you just hold to your neck twice a day for a few minutes. It's being trialed first for migraines and cluster headaches (which [sound horrible](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cluster_headache)). If it works, vagus nerve stimulation could compete directly with drug treatments on cost and convenience and it would let doctors find new ways to hack human physiology.
